page.title: 05BISHOPS BEFORE THE WAR contd
page.content: liver. The leef, the fat from the inside of the pig weighing 5lb-8lb was melted down to lard for eating on bread or toast and cooking. Butter was too expensive. Milk was delivered by horse and float, it was brought to the door in metal pails and measured into jugs. Coal was delivered by horse and dray. There was{no electricity}in the village; only outside toilets; no buses and very few cars. Horses and carts and bicycles were the main means of transport. Mr. J. Edwards (my great great uncle) ran a carrier's cart to{Leamington Spa}and{Banbury} market on Thursdays to fetch goods for people. There was a village policeman who patrolled the village on foot. There were no hooligans in those days, children treated the{policeman}and{ {schoolmasters}with respect.
